As the Buddhist student sat in meditation, he pondered the words of his religious leader. "But what about the concept of an eternal soul?" he asked. "Is it not a central tenet of our faith?"

His leader, a wise and aged monk, looked at him with a knowing smile. "My young friend, you must not get caught up in the limitations of doctrine. The soul is not eternal, for it is bound by the cycle of rebirth and death. It is but a fleeting thought, a momentary flicker of existence."

The Buddhist student was taken aback. "But what of the teachings of the Buddha himself? Did he not speak of the eternal nature of the soul?"

The monk chuckled. "Ah, my young friend, you must not confuse the teachings of the Buddha with the limitations of your own understanding. The Buddha taught us of the impermanence of all things, including the soul. It is but a mere concept, a tool for us to use in our quest for enlightenment."

The Buddhist student sat in silence for a moment, digesting the words of his leader. He knew that he had much to learn, and that the path to enlightenment was not always an easy one. And so, he thanked his leader and continued on his journey, filled with a sense of wonder and curiosity.
